38878807.review:
If you've ever played EV: Nova or Void Expanse, then this game is for you - it combines a top down open galaxy with a lucasarts style view when aboard stations, to deliver something pretty unique: real character,

The ships are plentiful, with upgrades and new gear all over - the upgrading of ships is straightforward - all the menus are clear and uncluttered, with simple stats and systems. The dialogue is well written and self aware, plus the game has many sci fi easter eggs dotted all over.

Combat is, as with all these newtonian top down games, a little bit hit and miss (pun intended) and seems to boil down to slugging matches and who can dump the most missiles out. However, it's still fun and the world offers you a LOT of ways to make money outside of combat.

Coupled with a fantastic soundtrack and soundscape, this is a fun distraction and well worth the asking price.

38392080.review:
Not bad, but could have been better. I recommend getting it if/when it goes on sale.

Needs a lot of polish; controls are sometimes awkward and UI needs polish, for example when you bring up your mission list, there's a "show me where" button, but this only highlights the system that the destination is in. You need to then click on that system to zoom into it, so that you can then click on your destination to set it as a waypoint. They really could have had a "add destination as waypoint" button straight from the mission screen. Autopilot also seems to be buggy. You're supposed to be able to press Z to turn on autopilot, but if the autopilot drives near a star, the autopilot "disengages" and there does not seem to be a way to re-engage the autopilot except to quit the game and relaunch it.

The main mission narrative is enjoyable, but there's way too much filler content. The game would have been better if shorter and more focused. Mining is not particularly fun, shooting garbage is not particularly fun, salvaging derelict ships is not particularly fun, taxying and acting as a courier is not particularly fun. Took me about 10 hours to beat the main game, and then another 5 hours to "shoot 1000 garbage", "completel 50 taxi missions", and all the other filler achievements. NPCs also felt shallow. You can do "random chat" with them, or read their biographies, but there's no incentive to care about any of this. Feels like there was a missed opportunity to have them deliver side quests to you.

There's basically 3 classes of ships in this game: traders, fighters, and all-arounders. When you get to the last boss, you can't switch your ship, so I got kind of screwed there because I had to do a massive boss fight in my trader ship. Took several tries and reloads but I eventually got it. Would have been nice if I could have just switched to a fighter ship for that boss fight though -- everywhere else in the game except for the introductory tutorial, you can switch your ships at will as long as you have the money.

The music was both a pro and a con for this game. There's some really nice track that give it that great 80s vibe. The thing is that they chose songs with lyrics, which means the music is very salient to the player, instead of being a background element. This is not necessarily bad, but because there's not that many different tracks in the game, it becomes very obvious very quickly when they start repeating the same tracks over and over. I think if you're going to use tracks with lyrics, you need to "use them once" for a set-piece moment. Take a look at how Saints Row uses the "I Need a Hero" or "Power" songs, for example.

This is a really pretty awesome game.  If you played Privateer or Privateer 2, it's certainly got some similarities.  Basically instead of a 3D piloting experience, it's top down and kind of gallaga-ish.  There's a lot of ships to buy and a lot of different options, and a crazy lot of stuff to explore and do.

What I like best is that it's a balance of detail and simple play.  A lot of these sorts of games get really overwhelming, but everything was pretty straight forward and enjoyable.  The hardest part (from my perspective) was learning how traveling between space systems work.  Hint: flying into the nebula is really bad :P

My only critique is that the time spent outside of your ship is pretty lame.  It's better than Privateer where all you got was a slightly animated picture and hot-spots to click, but I would enjoy getting to do more exploration of space stations and planets.  Part of the plot is reasons why you can't do this, so I doubt they'll ever take that direction, but "if it were my game..."  That's probably what I'd do :)

So yeah, I would highly recommend this one.

36451683.review:
I really wanted to love this game. Stylistically, it's really fun, and the plot arc is charming.
The classic space-trader-shooter process - getting money, upgrading your ship and getting more money with it - is nicely paced, and the combat is simple but engaging.
But that leads to the first problem: there's next to no combat. Going to a "dangerous" system means there might be one or two pirates hanging out, that you can avoid by just flying to where you want to go. The developers have tried to counter this by adding a menu option for extra fights, but even on the lowest setting this just means a steady stream of hit squads attacking you faster than you can kill them off, even if you're right outside a station in a safe area.
The second major problem for me is the "LucasArts Style" adventuring - there's two of them, with two puzzles between them, one featuring a character who directly tells you how to complete the puzzle. It feels misleading to include one of them in the screenshot gallery.

36203549.review:
It isn’t perfect. However, it is a solid little gem of a game that relies heavily on atmosphere and nostalgia. Truly a work that is greater than the sum of its parts. The elements found within are simple, yet they are used to the full extent of their dimensions. Like a green onion and cheddar omelet made by a world renown chef while the chef is hungover from a night of binge drinking, yet could still make this dish in their sleep. So lets get down to the gritty details.

Pros:  The soundtrack (while slightly fluffy and vapid at times) is quite catchy and will have you bobbing your head as long as nobody is around to see you and question your masculinity. The songs do borrow heavily from many highly recognizable songs from popular charts which will remain unnamed, but they do a good enough job of establishing themselves to be forgivable.

Tons of nostalgia and references to produce chuckles under your breath and make you feel special for knowing the thing that the game is talking about or depicting. You snowflake you! :p

Easy to grasp fun mechanics and controls.

Sufficient career options and upgrades to explore making the experience feel all that more expansive and inclusive.

Decently entertaining story which does a good job of immersing you in it.


Cons: Quests can seem repetitive and boring after grinding for a bit. 

Some elements aren’t very intuitive and feel buggy and/or frustrating at times such as bounty hunting or some elements of travel.


	All in all, this game is a lot of fun and shouldn’t disappoint anybody interested in the science fiction genre.

36069664.review:
After seeing so many positive reviews, I was impressed and decided to buy since I love just about anything Sci-Fi and leveling up weapons and spacecraft. About two hours in, I realized it was going to be pretty monotonous - the game, in essence, is travelling from one mini game to another which can be tedious and annoying. I find I end up spending a significant amount of game time on my facebook waiting for my ship again and again to cross the map to get to the next story point inevitably with some variation of the same mini game involved. The mini games include exploring extremely simple, and significantly uninteresting derelict ships, hauling junk from one part of the map to another for money, providing taxi services for money, and taking pictures of random people who don't have any story impact also for money (like you're helping people stalk others for money). I wasn't able to get a refund since I played it just over two hours before trying to return it, so as cheap as I am, I decided I'm just going to finish out the story, not do another unnecessary odd job/mini game within the game, and upgrade the ship and probably won't ever visit this title again. 

The dogfights are probably the most interesting thing about the game, but that's not saying much. With enough patience, and even with your first ship, you could literally take down any enemy ship simply by strafing around the enemy and shooting. They'll never be able to hit you with their shots and their missles you can blow up by pressing shift when the missle is in range to be self destructed. And that summarizes every dogfight, even if you have 5-10 ships shooting at you - Just strafe, blow up missles, shoot and you win. Simple.

Also, the dialogue is terrible, unwitty, and cliche. Even when the game tries to make fun of itself, it does so in a way that generally isn't humorous for anyone over the age of 10. It makes fun of itself so frequently, I begin to wonder if the developers intentionally put absurd things in the game just to create a dialogue that makes fun of it. Because they use vulgar language, they can't market the game towards what I think would be a more appropriate audience: children 10 and younger. 

Overall, the game is boring, uninteresting, monotonous, and simply, just not a very creative game. If you're still considering getting the game, definitely wait for a discount, or try it and be sure to return it within two hours which is all it takes really to experience just about everything the game has to offer without completing the story.

35089507.review:
Con 3030 Deathwar Redux estamos ante un magnifico simulador espacial donde, al igual que en otros juegos del género como la serie del X Universo, podemos comerciar, minar, cazar piratas, etc. Eso si, a diferencia de la serie X aquí tenemos dos tipos de persectiva: la primera, cuando viajamos en nuestra nave, sera de vista superior, al estilo de otros juegos como The Last Federation o el primer Space Pirates And Zombies, y la segunda, será cuando entremos en estaciones espaciales, bajemos a planetas, etc donde adoptaremos una vista de scroll lateral.

Al igual que otros simuladores espaciales de "mundo abierto" podremos jugar y seguir nuestro propio camino, seguir la historia principal o alternar entre ambas posibilidades. Y es en la historia principal donde el juego nos trae ciertas reminiscencia a las antiguas aventuras gráficas de LucasArts y similares: nos encontraremos con nuestro personaje principal, que guarda cierto parecido con cierto arqueólogo, teniendo que hablar con multitud de caracteres, tanto en busca de información valiosa para nuestras misiones como para simplemente ampliar el "lore" del universo... o para lanzarnos algún que otro guiño friki (el juego está lleno de humor y referencias).

Aunque los sistemas, planetas o estaciones espaciales tienen una ubicación fija, elementos como los campos de asteroides o las naves abandonadas que podemos saquear se crearan de forma dinámica y aleatoria (de forma que el jugador que decida conseguir creditos con la mineria o el "salvamento" siempre tenga donde hacerlo). Tampoco faltan piratas, naves desconocidas y "criaturas" a los que dar caza si nos decantamos por el combate.

Para los que decidan dedicarse al comercio hay gran cantidad de recursos englobados en una economia dinámica con los que conseguir beneficios (típico sistema de "en el sector A el titanio se vende muy barato y en el sistema B se compra muy caro), un buen número de naves (desde pequeñas y rápidas naves para el combate, a grandes y lentas naves de transporte, pasando por naves militares) con sus correspondintes mejoras y actualizaciones. Naturalmente tampoco faltaran los típicos trabajos de chico de los paquetes, taxi, etc, con los que hacer dinero rápido.

En definitiva, un gran juego lleno de detalles, humor y muchas horas de juego si te gusta el género... y no esperas gráficos ultraHD 8k, claro.



Un saludo.

35037073.review:
A whole lot to like here.

Procedurally generated missions with several varieties available, a well-written main campaign, a fairly large number of systems to explore, and atmosphere that will appeal to folks who remember the eighties.  

There are many ways to play--I started with "taxi" missions within a system, eventually getting enough to run salvage operations on derelicts, then upgrading to a well-rounded ship capable of bounty hunting, then finally strip-mining of asteroid belts.  You need to save your game, unlike most console titles now, but I've found 3030 is fairly forgiving of missteps, I'd have killed me for running out of fuel.  Strongly recommended for sandbox gamers and folks with limited game time.

Pretty good soundtrack, but it begins to get repetitive after ten hours.

A fair number of ship models to choose from but I would have liked more.  The upgrade modules are where 3030 shines; too lazy to get missiles?  Mount a second gun and some maneuvering thrusters.  Love mining?  Get the expensive tractor beam.  Took several hours before I began to see these, but it did not feel like much of a grind.

Some warts and odd design choices--I love the upgrade system but sorting by type or draggable 'modules' would have been more intuitive.  The random name generator gives male names to a lot of female-looking models.  The in-game tutorial is okay but you are expected to figure stuff out for yourself, and some things are just not explained or intuitive, like the "photo missions."  

Overall, a strong title with 50+ hours of play in it for the average gamer, and it is a steal at under twenty bucks.

Don't forget to refuel! Buy it and enjoy for a long time (I imagine, just getting into it and not sure of the story's length but the structure seems to have alot aspects to explore, engage and exploit). 34962811.review:
This little indy game stratches an itch that no AAA space sim has been able to for years.

From the moment I started zipping around in my little shuttle, learning all the systems and taking passangers and packages from station to station, this game has drawn me in so deeply. Its graphics and banter are quirky in the best of ways and really make for a surprisingly immersive experience. 

The missions vary and you're able to play all the fun roles you've come to expect from space-faring games. Sure, the missions do get a bit repeatative and some pay out much more than others, but the main story is broken up in a way that keeps drawing you in with every snippet you see. 

The game seems to have a lot going on at first, but it's never felt overwhelming to me at all - even without hand-holding. I recommend using keyboard/mouse controls and taking the time to go watch a 2hr+ gameplay video before buying it, but at the current price, it's so very much worth it. The soundtrack is great, but keep in mind that if you do watch videos online, you won't hear it due to copyrights. 

I'm just getting started, but I can already tell I'll sink an easy 40+ hours into this gem of a game. 

If you like space games and retro design done in a superbly modern way, don't hesitate to get this one.

11/10, I can't stop squashing every bug on every console in the galaxy. 
It's my obsession.

34958235.review:
Ich muss den Entwickler dieses Indie-Juwels hier ganz klar meine Anerkennung aussprechen, so viel Liebe zum Detail hab ich selten gesehen, man merkt das hier jede menge Herzblut hineingeflossen ist. Hut ab!

Ganz zu schweigen von den vielen Allusionen und versteckten Details der Pop-Kultur der 80er und 90er, in fast jeder Station gibt es was zu entdecken, herrlich. Klar das muss man mögen, da ich aber in dieser Zeit aufgewachsen bin und es recht gut in das ohne hin etwas schrullige Universum passt das hier konstruiert wurden, kann man auch ohne Hintergrundwissen über diese Zeit bestimmt gut damit leben.

Nach ungefähr 6 Stunden (Offline-Modus wird wohl nicht mitgerechnet) hab ich knapp 1/3 der 38 Sonnensysteme bereist und bin dabei mehr oder weniger geradlinig der Story gefolgt. Wodurch ich eine theoretische Spielzeit von 20 Stunden herausbekomme. Vorausgesetzt ich werde mich nach der Story nicht noch als Space-Trucker verdingen, naja wird wohl eher doch mehr...

Die Auswahl der Raumschiffe reicht von Taxi-Shuttels über Abfangjäger und Mittelschwere Fregatten bis hin zum großen Handelspott, mit unzähligen Upgrades. Da ist für jeden Spielstil das richtige dabei. Zu den annehmbaren Aufträgen zählen unter anderem Personen- und Gegenstandtransporte, Schwerlasttransporte via Traktor-Strahl, das bespitzel von Personen oder kartografieren von Planeten so wie das Zerstören von Weltraumtrümmern und der Klassiker, das Eliminieren von Piraten. Außerdem können noch Wracks von havarierten Raumschiffen geplündert werden.

Mit der Steuerung kam ich nach kurzer Eingewöhnung gut zurecht und dank der Trägheit entsteht ein angenehmes Semi-Realistisches Gefühl der Raumschiffe, vor allem im "Split" genannten Sprungantrieb zwischen den Systemen. Da ich eher ein friedliebender Handelsvertreter bin und äh ja, schon ein alter Sack, kommen mir die Kämpfe etwas hektisch und unübersichtlich vor, soweit ich das beurteilen kann sind aber die meisten Auseinandersetzungen optional.

Also ich bin dem Spiel verfallen und würde es den Entwickler wünschen wenn es noch mehr Spielern so ergeht.

Ganz klare Kaufempfehlung!

34923588.review:
It's indy, It's fresh, It's Retro, It's everything this Gen X gamer craves.   

I Grew up in the 80s and 90s, back then was the golden age of PC adventure gaming. Star control, space Quest, Star Trek the 25th-anniversary game and many others would keep me and my pals awake till odd hours of the night.  Trying to complete these games in record time, or with better scores, or just figure them out in the first place.  For a long time, I've had the itch to relive that kind of gaming experience. 

3030 Deathwar Redux manages to scratch that itch in a very novel way.   Without the constraints of being too "realistic" or "edgy" or "simulator" oriented, the devs are able to tell a story free from the shackles of having to EXPLAIN the science of it all, while at the same time, reference countless sci fi genre tropes with blatantly in your face easter eggs. 

For anyone who has played and loved Games like Star Control or especially Space Quest, you will instantly appreciate this. 

I have only had a short time with the game, and I can already see myself enjoying the open world space exploration and combat, and the humorous story and dialogue are right up my alley keeping it fresh and fun. 

It doesn't hold your hand too much, you have to figure a few things out as you go, but it does a fair job of guiding you to learning the ropes as you play.  Gently suggesting at the next reasonable course of action to get yourself back on track ASAP. 

It's not a perfect game by any means, and if you aren't into the brand of humor and gameplay it uses to tell it's a story you might not care for it at all.  If all you care about are high rez 3d computer crushing graphics, super easy linear shooters or anything like that, you probably won't want this game. However, had this come out in the 80s or 90s, it would have been a classic that would have shaped a generation of gamers perception of how to do a space sci fi game for the next decade.  

If you still have a soft spot for the old classics like the ones I mentioned at the start, you need grab this game and make a nice hot Tea and sit down on a rainy day and give this a whirl.  For the price of a movie ticket you will have more than your moneys worth.

29193910.review:
John Falcon is not your typical hero, he dresses weird, tends to talk big, and really loves money. He kind of reminds me of Jack Burton from Big Trouble in Little China.(Btw GREAT movie) Bad luck and bad decisions just seem to go hand in hand with this guy. Due to some crazy prophecy dealing with bird names and a ship loaded to the ceiling with gold, all scavengers get a bullseye on their heads. This is where our story begins and things get even more crazy, with interesting characters, factions, and of course space travel.

3030 Death War Redux is an open space simulator, now the "Redux" part means that this is a revitalization. It's important to note because I didn't play the game back in its original heyday. I have only played this new version of the game. So keep in mind this won't be a comparison of the two but more of analyzation of what is in the game now. From what I understand, the graphics, story, side quests, balancing and a whole plethora of things are getting the overhaul from the previous iteration.

Usually, when I play these types of games, I find them to be almost exactly like space itself, a dark vacuum of nothing and where everything takes forever to do. Thankfully, I was pleasantly surprised by the amount of content and missions but more importantly, the universe felt alive.  Boarding any station, greeted me every time with a slew of strange aliens, alien interiors, and quirky conversations. It was like the Star Wars cantina scene and I honestly couldn't get enough. This is one of the areas the game absolutely shines as you go about from station to station, collecting missions, making contacts, and trying to stay alive. Even arriving at a station was a dazzling display of holographic ad ships, and other kinds of ships buzzing in and out.

Over all, the mechanics are very reminiscent of the genre. You start with nothing and build yourself up. You can trade, escort, pick up cargo, bounty hunt, and perform many other tasks to build up your cash and eventually get a bigger, badder ship. One thing that I found unique to 3030 was the ability to scavenge derelict space ships for supplies, cargo, etc. The few times I did manage to find a destroyed vessel, my pulse would begin to race, wondering what I might find. You can't see very far and only have a small scanning droid to assist you locate items of importance. This is one area I definitely would love for them to expand on. Turn up the horror aspect and add some procedural design and scavenging can be practically its own game, if done right.

Another area that absolutely blew my mind was the games soundtrack. I don't say this very often but 3030 has one of the best and most well integrated soundtracks. The music has this awesome techno synth thing going that seems shot out of the 80's. You might think that doesn't work with this type of game but it really, really does. There are also some other instrumental pieces and alternative choices as some of the songs are licensed, and may cause an issue for streamers/youtubers.

Keep in mind that 3030 is in Early Access, so there is still things that need polish and attention. The game crashed a few times on me randomly. Also the UI isn't the most user friendly, I seriously wish there was a way to zoom in. If you play the game you will feel as if you are unnaturally far away from the action. I don't know if this is intended or something that is going to be addressed. The graphics/art style themselves are rather appealing to the eye. Consoles are rusted or dirty, other parts of the station show inhabitants going about their daily lives. Screens flicker with news and bartenders stroll back and forth. The galaxy itself looks great, with nebulas, stars, and everything in between. I just wish I could see it a bit better.

One of the biggest gripes I came away with was the combat in 3030. Combat is a bit of a mess and I still didn't quite understand the finer points after about six hours of playing. You have missiles and lasers and more or less just ending up shooting each other in the face and hope you have more hit-points. This is going back to the camera just being placed so far away that pin pointing shots is downright exasperating at times. Taking on more then one enemy is a logistical nightmare and sadly, enemies tend to attack in large groups. I tried using the different movement modes and found the same results. While I am not sure how to fix the combat, I can tell you it wasn't my favorite aspect for sure.

Thankfully combat isn't the most important aspect to the game, but it is obviously vital. I personally would recommend avoiding combat like the plague, but your mileage may vary. Plus there are more than enough other activities that can earn you tons of cash.

When you look at space simulators, they are a very ambitious type of game. You have almost as much work as someone would do for an MMORPG but for a single player game. Not only do you have to fine tune your basic mechanics of combat, but you have to micro manage dozens of systems such as factions, economy, and any story you may want to have. It's no small task and not an easy one, so obviously I will reserve judgement for final release. That being said the most important part for me, in these types of games, is an aspect that 3030 Deathwar Redux already has in oodles. It has personality, charm, and the universe feels alive.

Plus any game that throws in Crow T. Robot as a bartender has got my vote. So keep an eye on this one folks!

25239112.review:
[h1] 3030 Deathwar Redux [/h1]

DISCLAIMER: I received this product for no cost for the purpose of reviewing. However, this does not affect my views and opinions of the game.

3030 Deathwar Redux is a 2D open-world space adventure, though there are elements of many other genres within the game. Most of the time you spend the game flying your ship from place to place completing tasks, and when you're doing so, the game plays like the old-school game; "Asteroids" or other spaceship shooters. The rest of the time, your character is either on space stations picking up new jobs, trading, and talking to people OR at derelicts salvaging materials and other items. There is a variety of things to do within the game, and there is SOME element of choice making as well. The game may remind some people of "Space Pirates and Zombies", though I feel like this title offers a very unique experience on it's own.

--------

[b] Graphics: 8 / 10 [/b]

Art-style is subjective, and at first I didn't really enjoy the pixel design of the game (and usually I do). After playing the game for awhile, the style of the game really grew on me. The graphics of the game are really well done. The style is unique, and it gives the game a lot of charm. There's an abundance of characters and races, each with their own unique and interesting design. Most of the space-stations and derelicts you enter look kinda the same internally (with the exception of small details), though the exterior appearance of these places are really different and neat. Of course, this game's motif is space, so there is a ton of space themed objects, designs and graphics, though the game puts them together quite nicely. While traveling in space, there's usually a lot happening on screen. There's cargo ships, police and other vessels just roaming around (which you can interact with). When you're not around a station however, just traveling to another place, there isn't a whole lot happening aside from you passing by planets, asteroids, and derelicts IF you see them. The game is not too demanding, it should run fine on a low - mid-tier graphics card and CPU. 

--------

[b] Sound: 8 / 10 [/b]

The sound assets are just fine. All the gun sounds, ambient space sounds, and general space themed noises are great and fit right in with theme of the game. The main reason this game ranks so well in it's sound category is because of the amazing soundtrack/background music that plays throughout the game. There are quite a bit of beautiful vocal tracks within the game as well as some instrumentals. The only complaint I'd have about this is that; tracks don't loop or switch to another track after finishing. Though this is a minor personal gripe as you're usually not in space long enough for the track to finish (though sometimes you are). This also might annoy or bother some players because they might deem it as "repetitive" sounds. All in all, the soundtrack is amazing and I really hope they release an OST. 

--------

[b] Mechanics: 8 / 10 [/b] 

The mechanics are really well-done. There's so much to do in the game, though that being said, it is possible that the game might feel repetitive after "grinding" out side-jobs for cash. The good news is that there's a lot of different things you can do for cash. Some of these things depend on the kind of ship you own, and what kind of upgrades you have, but these things are not that difficult to obtain. The most basic thing you can do is dock at various space-stations and use the job console to find jobs; these kind of jobs include taxi services, package deliveries, trash clean-up, photo-taking, towing services and a few more that you can unlock through playing the game. Some of these jobs have time limits, and having a faster ship may be helpful. Some of these jobs also require you to have a certain amount of cabins or cargo space on your ship.   
 
There are also bounties you can take from the job console which help you hunt down space pirates for more cash, as well as loot their ships. Completing/not completing these jobs can impact your reputation which can have effects on various things or conversations. You can also find space pirates in each space system without having to take a "mission" for it. Sometimes civilians on space stations will also have jobs for you when you talk to them. You can also harvest asteroid fields for minerals and ore which you can sell at trade consoles. Trade consoles are also at space stations. Each station sells and buys goods at different prices, so trading is another way cash can be made. 

Another way to make cash within the game is to become a pirate yourself. You can ram into cargo ships, destroy civilian ships and work at pirate outposts. Though usually this gets you in trouble with the law, as well as places a bounty on your head. There may be other ways to make cash later on in the game. There are also a few random events that happen every now and then that may grant the player rewards.

The flying and combat in the game is simple. You use the arrow keys to move around and hit the space and enter keys to fire off your weapons. The movement style is sort of like those other float-y movement space-shooters. You can buy different weapons and missiles to fit to your ship, as well as other ship upgrades. Not all ships can be fitted with the same equipment, so knowing which ships are good for battle and which are good for other missions is important. Although this might not affect everyone; the controls of the game take a while to get used to as they don't feel right or comfortable when first played (for both flying in space and walking around). 

-------- 

[b] Final Personal Remarks: [/b]

The first time I played the game I wasn't too keen on the graphic style, like I said earlier, it really grew on me. There are some aspects of the game I don't partake in (such as derelicts) because I still haven't completely gotten used to the design. That being said, I still think the game looks great. The story seems really interesting, and it looks like you unlock and discover new things as you go through it. The game's tone is a little humorous and actually does have neat references. The dialogue in the game is great, and is actually worth reading in my opinion. The devs spent a lot of time with the dialogue, as there's so much of it from almost every NPC you meet. The game has a real charm and I really enjoy games like this where you have to try and make money somehow, but also gives you so many ways to do so. The music is lovely and I wish there was an OST or something somewhere. The game is currently in early access but has lots to offer. Even though more and more features are being added to the game, I believe it's already really good as it is.

Thanks to "[url=https://pcgamesnnews.wordpress.com/]PC Games n News[/url]" for giving me the opportunity to review the game, as well as anyone who took this review into consideration, I hope it helped.

24258627.review:
I also covered this game on YouTube: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5ghDdYK618s

3030 Deathwar Redux is an update to a remake of a 2007 indie game. Confusing I know but it's to the game's benefit.

This is an open-galaxy space adventure with a mid-90s DOS aesthetic. There's a story which you can follow or not as you choose and there's also a variety of activities to undertake, including trading, one-off missions, piracy and scavenging derelicts for resources which can be used to upgrade your ship and its capabilities. The core concept are very much reminiscent of older games in the genre like Privateer, Freelancer or even Elite to a certain degree. The story seems kind of generic and goofy but in a Firefly sort of way that doesn't take itself at all seriously which I can appreciate.

People are either going to find the retro graphics endearing or eye burning. I'm very much in the former camp, as someone who grew up in that era of gaming. It also has the advantage of making the game's requirements very low, so you can easily play it on lower power laptops when on the go. It contols entirely with the keyboard as well. The soundtrack is incredibly varied and diverse and while a lot of the songs seem contextually out of place, it's still great to see so many different tracks available in some many genres. You'll spend a lot of time travelling out in space so having good stuff to listen to is always a bonus.

My complaints with it at this stage of development are the mission variety and that scavenging hulks is painfully samey. The missions are the usual crop of delivery, bounty hunting or transport missions but that's kind of it. Some more mixing up of that would be nice. In addition, scavenging a derelict literally just involves flying up to it, watching an animation, moving down a tiny hallway that never has anything in it but the loot, picking up the loot and watching another animation. The developers have said they plan to flesh this out more and I hope they do.

Make no mistake, this is a game that pays homage to the old school "space trucking" genre and has every intention to. If you're not into that, you won't be into this but if you are, it's a good time that can be enjoyed in short or long sessions. I plan to cover the game again once it hits final release and I'm anxious to see the new content additions at that point. Even now though, it's a good time if you like this kind of thing.

22702500.review:
DISCLAIMER: The developer of this game gave me a copy because I donanted to the orginal release. 
Also, most of my experience is with the orginal game and I'm still feeling out the new one.

3030 Deathwar is a good space game. It has all the top-down real-time space stuff you could ask for in a large open-roam universe, trading, quests, combat and even some adventure. The trading is simple but well implemented, stuff is worth more in different systems and you can play the market to your benefit while steadily upgrading to bigger and bigger ships. The quests are also well-done with the usual variation, combat, delivey, discovery, salvage, mining, bounty-hunting, etc. The combat is like a souped-up version of Asteriod, control your momentum, dodge the enemy's bullets and missle while firing your own.

The games main strengths lie in its writing and its music. While every station is much the same format of bar, hanger, trade and job areas, each character you encounter (and there are so many) has a little dialogue tree and intresting things to say. In fact, the adventuring and dialogue trees are great in that they call back to old choose-your-own-adventure and point'n'click adventure games while meshing into the actual space-flying-around-part. Also the music is great, up-beat and catchy pop for flying around and suitable instrumental stuff for the adventure parts.

The main weaknesses of the game came from it's Early Access nature. There aren't as many resolutions as you'd hope, there's no option to change the controls from flying with the arrows to flying with WASD (a personal bugbear of mine) and some the story quests aren't as flexible as they should be. For example, in an early story quest somebody was gunning for me and, being out-gunned, I ran away to another system. I was then treated to a little pixel cutscene implying I killed the guy I ran away from.

All-in-all though, a solid, quirky game they may actually end up sucking away hours upon hours of your time.

Скучная и однообразная.
Да, есть открытый мир, есть торговля, миссии, но проблема в том, что это все не имеет смысла.
Корабли отличаются только вместимостью и наличию турели, максимум вооружения для самого навороченного корабля это одна турель, одна пушка и до 10 ракет. Сами пушки отличаются только скорострельносью и наносимым уроном, все они стреляют прямо.
Если у вас есть турель, противоракетная шняга и ускорители, то можно пересрелять всех и все, что можно пристрелить, просто наворачивая круги вокруг жертв.
Основной квест относительно короткий, унылый и поверхностный, никакой интриги, выбора, неожиданных поворотов, просто таскайся между станциями до конца. Местный юмор тож как-то не оч.
Миссии на станциях это принеси-отнеси, постреляй по мусору, прибей пирата, пофоткай планету/нпс в одном конце галактики и отнеси фотки в другой конец галактики. Еще можно лутать останки кораблей, но там мышь сломать можно.
Самый быстрый и прибыльный путь это пиратство - мочить всех и продавать их лут на пиратской станции. Когда надоест - откупиться.
В плюсах только музыка и визуальный стиль.
А ведь можно было сделать, хотя бы, аналог космических рейнджеров. И ведь могло получиться.
